channel.title: JURIST - News - Legal News & Commentary
channel.description: Serious law. Primary sources. Global perspective.

item.title: Alabama AG requests federal investigation of 2017 election---HOLD
item.dc:creator: arundell
item.content:encoded: Alabama Attorney General Steve Marshall asked federal election officials on Monday to investigate reports of deceptive tactics in the U.S. Senate race in 2017, in which Doug Jones (D) defeated incumbent Roy Moore (R). The Attorney General's office shared its concerns with the U.S. Federal Election Committee that the race was compromised due to use of a misleading social media campaign against Moore. Mike Lewis, a spokesperson for Marshall stated that "the Attorney General has requested that FEC officials investigate the matter to determine if any federal laws were violated," finding the issue to be in exclusive jurisdiction of the federal government.

item.title: Former Romania chief anti-corruption prosecutor sues over firing---HOLD
item.dc:creator: zuram
item.content:encoded: On Tuesday a former chief anti-corruption prosecutor in Romania sued her country's government in the European Court of Human Rights over her firing. Laura Codruta Kovesi was fired by the Justice Minister last July for allegedly abusing her authority and mismanagement. The President refused to follow through with the removal but Romanian Constitutional Court ordered her removal. Kovesi said, "she was sacked unfairly and had her rights violated when she was denied the right to appeal a Constitutional Court decision that ordered her firing." Romania is now in control of the rotating presidency of the European Union and is under scrutiny for their contentious judicial overhaul critics say is designed to protect corrupt officials. The European Commission had released a statement against the overhaul.

item.title: House Democrats introduce bill to expand background checks on gun sales
item.dc:creator: tbrown
item.content:encoded: On Tuesday, House Democrats introduced a bill that would expand background checks on gun sales. The bill would require background checks on most gun purchases, "including those sold at gun shows and over the internet." However, there would be some exceptions for guns for law enforcement officers as well as for "guns transferred between close family members." The bill would also provide exceptions for transfers to executors of estates, as well as "temporary transfers of weapons for the purpose of hunting or to 'prevent imminent death or great bodily harm.'" The bill "will almost certainly pass the House" but may have a harder time passing in the Senate.

item.title: Second Honduran caravan starts trek to US-Mexico border---HOLD
item.dc:creator: lmoffutt
item.content:encoded: A second honduran caravan on Monday, began making its way to the US border through Mexico with nearly 800 people following, despite US government push-back during the first caravan attempt. The news has fueled President Donald Trump's efforts to motivate Congress to approve funding for the US-Mexico border wall build. The efforts seem to be motivated by the same issues concerning the first caravan effort--growing gang violence, drug wars and corruption in Honduras. Though the US government is at a standstill over the US-Mexico border wall, federal courts have largely denied or punted President Trump's latest efforts to strengthen and enhance immigration and border patrol policies. The US Supreme Court in December denied the Trump administration's request to enforce new asylum rules set forth in Presidential Proclamation November 9, which sought to immediately deny asylum to migrants who illegally cross the southern border into the US.  Also in December, a federal judge denied an ex parte application for stay of proceedings in the latest lawsuit brought by various immigrant child advocacy organizations against the US government for actions concerning immigrant children.

item.title: The Supreme Court of Pakistan ordered union councils to register Christian marriages --- HOLD
item.dc:creator: tbrown
item.content:encoded: On Wednesday, the Supreme Court of Pakistan ordered "union councils across the country to start registering marriages of Christian couples." The court ordered the councils to register marriages of Christian couples. The National Database and Registration Authority (NADRA) was also ordered "to issue computerised marriage certificates to married Christian couples." Previously, the marriages of Christian couples were not registered by union councils, but with churches.

item.title: Theresa May wins No-Confidence Vote.---HOLD
item.dc:creator: zuram
item.content:encoded: On Wednesday United Kingdom Prime Minister Theresa May won a no-confidence vote 325-306. The vote if triggered would have brought about new elections during the Brexit negotiations heightening the chances of a no-deal hard Brexit in March. The no-confidence vote followed the overwhelming defeat of May's Brexit bill in Parliament on Tuesday. Following her government winning the vote of confidence the Prime Minister did not rule out the possibility of the "no-deal." She also called for a meeting with the heads of the other political parties, "I stand ready to work with any member of this House to deliver on Brexit." Currently, there are six different potential outcomes from the vote. First, there could be a new Brexit deal negotiated and voted on. Second, the hard Brexit on March 27th without a deal. Third, another no-confidence vote. Fourth, a second referendum on Brexit. Fifth a call for new elections and finally a second vote on the bill May put forth.

item.title: Federal judge finds PG&E equipment was recurring cause in California wildfires---HOLD
item.dc:creator: eslobe
item.content:encoded: Judge William Alsup of the US District Court for the Northern District of California declared in a preliminary finding on Thursday that Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E) equipment was a common cause of California wildfires in 2017 and 2018 that have been attributed to PG&E. The court determined that based on evidence presented, uninsulated power conductors are often pushed together due to fallen trees or limbs. This then caused sparks to fall on the vegetation below which pose an "extreme danger" of starting a wildfire. The parties to the case (PG&E and the United States of America) have until January 23 to respond to the preliminary finding and a hearing will be held on January 30. PG&E is accused of starting wildfires through reckless operation or maintenance of its power lines. The California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection has not concluded investigations into the 2018 Camp Fire or other 2018 wildfires, but the law suit states that the organization found evidence of state law violations in eleven 2017 wildfires. PG&E is currently facing bankruptcy over the potential liability for damages due to the 2017 and 2018 wildfires. Not including punitive damages or fines, PG&E is facing $30 billion in damages. The Attorney General for California indicated in an amicus brief filed in December that PG&E could also face murder or involuntary manslaughter charges for the wildfires.

item.title: President Trump and several Latin American countries recognize Juan Guaido as Venezuelan President---DNP
item.dc:creator: zuram
item.content:encoded: On Wednesday, President Trump recognized Juan Guaido as Interim President of Venezuela

item.title: National Labor Relations Board holds that SuperShuttle drivers are not employees---HOLD
item.dc:creator: chsu
item.content:encoded: On Friday, the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) held that drivers who drive for SuperShuttle DFW (Dallas-Fort Worth) are not employees of SuperShuttle. By the board's review, the drivers are considered independent contractors. The decision, as far as the NLRB is concerned, marks the agency's return to a US Supreme Court-set common law standard applicable when determining whether workers are independent contractors or employees. In a 3-to-1 decision, members of the NLRB board chose to apply the multi-factor scenario-specific test first adopted by the US Supreme Court case, National Labor Relations Board v. United Insurance Company of America, 390 U.S. 254 (1968). In that case, the Supreme Court noted that Section 2(3) of the National Labor Relations Act did not distinguish between "employees" and "independent contractors". To determine whether a worker is an employer or an independent contractor, the Supreme Court rule takes into account factors such as: the circumstantial relationship between the employer and the worker, the degree of skill required to perform the work, whether the employer supplies any capital (ei. tools, equipment, etc.) necessary for the performance of the work, and whether or not the work itself is essential to the day-to-day conducing of the employer's business. The Supreme Court listed 10 factors, but maintained that not every one of the factors listed need apply. In addition, more factors may be taken into consideration. Moreover, no individual factor is determinant. Nevertheless, the commonality shared among most of the delineated factors tend to revolve around the degree of "control" the employer and workers exert over the work activity. Consequentially, the NLRB's decision focused particularly heavily on the degree of control exerted by SuperShuttle over its DFW Airport drivers. The board noted the minimal degree of control SuperShuttle retains regarding when drivers' work, and the manner or amount of compensation they receive. Notably the drivers enter contractual agreements with SuperShuttle with the explicit understanding that drivers are to be considered independently contractual "franchisee's", and not as employees. Drivers are expected to provide their own vehicles which they will be licensed to use SuperShuttle's trademark logos. Drivers work whenever they wish while being required to pay SuperShuttle a periodic fee to continue to use the SuperShuttle trademark.

item.title: U.S. District Court Judge allows environmental suit against Army Corps of Engineers to go forward---HOLD
item.dc:creator: ofrance
item.content:encoded:
United States District Judge, James Robart, of the United States District Court, Western District of Washington at Seattle, denied the Army Corps of Engineers (Corps) motion to dismiss the lawsuit brought against them by a coalition of environmental groups consisting of Sound Action, Washington Environmental Council, and Friends of the San Juans (plaintiffs) who are interested in the protection and restoration of Puget Sound’s shorelines and water bodies. The plaintiffs their complaint that the Corps shoreline armoring of the Puget Sound is harmful to the marine shoreline ecosystem in the region through it "actions, and in-actions, in implementing federal laws. Shoreline armoring, or stabilizing the shoreline, involves the construction of seawalls, bulkheads, and similar structures, and the Corps contends that their actions are necessary to prevent detrimental erosion of the shoreline. In it's effort to dismiss the suit the Corps argued that the plaintiffs lacked standing to sue. A person has Article III standing to sue if (1) he or she suffered an injury in fact that is concrete, particularized, and actual or imminent; (2) the injury is fairly traceable to the challenged conduct; and (3) the injury is likely to be redressed by a favorable court decision. Judge Robart found that the plaintiffs met at least two of the criteria,
At the outset, the court finds that Plaintiffs meet the last two criteria for organizational standing, which the Corps does not challenge. See Friends of the Earth, 528 U.S. at 181; (see generally Mot.) Specifically, Plaintiffs are non-profit organizations dedicated to the protection and restoration of the Puget Sound. (Compl. ¶¶ 8-10.) Plaintiffs’ members assert health, recreational, environmental, aesthetic, and commercial interests in the Puget Sound’s shorelines and water bodies. (Id. ¶ 11.) These members rely on Plaintiffs to represent their interests in protecting and restoring the Puget Sound’s shorelines and water bodies. (See id. ¶¶ 8-11.) Accordingly, the interests at stake in this litigation are germane to Plaintiffs’ purposes and the participation of individual members in the lawsuit is not required. Therefore, the crux of the standing inquiry is whether Plaintiffs’ members would otherwise have standing to sue in their own right. At this stage, the court answers this question in the affirmative.
One of the main issues cited by the plaintiffs is the location of the high water mark. They contend that the Corps placement of the high water mark is below the recognized standard high water mark and allows avoidance of Federal review under their interpretation of the Clean Water Act's (CWA) high water jurisdictional boundary. This action by the Corps also extends to avoidance of review of other Federal regulations including the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA), and the Endangered Species Act (ESA). Several intergovernmental agencies including the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), the West Coast Region of the National Oceanic & Atmospheric Administration (“NOAA”) have recommended to the Corps that they change their high water mark and they have so far refused and the plaintiffs argue that "The Corps’ decision to summarily discard this analysis and maintain an unlawful jurisdictional boundary is arbitrary and capricious under the Administrative Procedure Act (“APA”), 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)."

item.title: Germany's cabinet approves abortion law revision --- DNP
item.dc:creator: tbrown
item.content:encoded: On Wednesday, Germany's cabinet approved a revision to the current abortion law. The revision would allow medical providers to advertise and provide information about abortion services. Currently, doctors are not allowed to advertise or provide information about abortion services, although first trimester abortions are legal under German law. If the revision passes, then medical providers would be allowed to advertise and provide information about the abortion services that they provide. Additionally, the "German Medical Association would also be allowed to compile a list of doctors and hospitals that offered the procedure."

item.title: Pennsylvania district court grants permanent injunction against company for adulteration of drugs---HOLD
item.dc:creator: atomlinson
item.content:encoded: The U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania granted a consent decree of permanent injunction on Wednesday against Rainer's Rx Laboratory, Inc, and its owner Francis H. Ranier, prohibiting both from manufacturing, hold, or distributing human or animal sterile drugs compounded at their facility until they comply with Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act and Food and Drug Administration (FDA) regulations due to finding that conditions at their facility was unsanitary. A complaint, filed by the Department of Justice on behalf of the FDA, alleged that Rainer's manufactured and distributed sterile drug products that were adulterated due their manufacture in unsanitary conditions causing them to become contaminated with filth or potentially injurious to others' health. According to inspection conducted by the FDA, such inadequate conditions considered "[u]nsanitary employee practices, poor aseptic technique, failure to ensure adequate air quality in the cleanroom, and inadequate environmental and personnel monitoring."o Parties agreed to a settlement, in which Rainer's, and owner, agreed to not resume business operations in regards to sterile products until they comply with the stipulated corrective actions, including "retaining an independent person to assist with remedial efforts, submitting a work plan to FDA, and providing a certification from the independent expert that defendants have undertaken corrective actions to ensure that defendants' facility, equipment, processes, and procedure are adequate to prevent defendants' drugs from becoming adulterated based on insanitary conditions." In July, the FDA announced a warning alerting healthcare professionals and consumers that any sterile products, both human and animal, produced by Rainer's may not be sterile. Later that same month, Rainer's voluntary issued a recall of all its unexpired sterile compounded drug products.

item.title: El Chapo is found guilty of all federal charges --- HOLD
item.dc:creator: rmoore
item.content:encoded:
A federal court on Tuesday found Joaquin Guzman Loera, also known as the drug lord "El Chapo", guilty of all 10 of the federal criminal charges brought against him. The U.S. government accused Guzman of trafficking drugs into the country for over two decades, laundering money, and leading the Sinaloa cartel, charges that could potentially carry a life sentence. The evidence prosecutors presented at trial include:
Testimony from 14 cooperating witnesses; narcotics seizures totaling over 130,000 kilograms of cocaine and heroin; weapons, including AK-47s and a rocket-propelled grenade launcher; ledgers; text messages; videos; photographs and intercepted recordings, detailed the drug trafficking activity of Guzman Loera and his co-conspirators over a 25-year period from January 1989 until December 2014. 
After 2 1/2 months of trial, it took the anonymous jury thirty-four hours over the span of six days to reach a verdict. June 25th is the tentative sentencing date for Guzman. His defense team are planning to appeal the conviction.

item.title: Group of women file lawsuit against Shell for 1995 military executions---HOLD
item.dc:creator: lmoffutt
item.content:encoded: A group of Ogoni women faced a court in the Netherlands for a lawsuit they filed against Royal Dutch Shell in 2017 for its complicity in the 1995 military executions of their husbands following a peaceful uprising against Shell's pollution in Ogoniland.  Esther Kiobel, wife of Dr. Barinem Kiobel- an Ogoni activist who was member of the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (MOSOP)- filed the lawsuit in June 2017, saying Shell played a role in the Nigerian military executions of nine Ogoni men (together known as the "Ogoni Nine"), after they protested alongside 300,000 others against Shell's pollution in the area. The uprising called for an end to Shell's carelessness in polluting Ogoniland.  Shell has continuously denied all claims against it and any involvement in the executions. Amnesty International has accused Shell of urging the Nigerian government to stop the protests, despite knowing that military force would lead to human rights violations against the protestors. Kiobel and three other widows filed the lawsuit in the Netherlands after failed attempts to prosecute the action in the US. The women appealed the US case to the Supreme Court, which ultimately denied review.

item.title: Canada's top court denies accreditation to Christian law school that banned gay sex
item.dc:creator: peckerd
item.content:encoded:
Canada's top court on Friday ruled in favor of denying accreditation to a Christian law school that made students sign an agreement that they would not have gay or premarital sex.
Trinity Western University in British Columbia initially applied for accreditation in every Canadian province so that its students could be called to the bar anywhere in Canada. Ontario, British Columbia and Nova Scotia law societies denied the school accreditation based on the school's required agreement.
While lower courts in Nova Scotia and British Columbia sided with the university, Ontario upheld the law society's decision to deny the school accreditation. As a result, the case made its way to Canada's top court.
The court found that the interest in supporting diversity and preventing inequitable barriers in Canada's law profession trumped the University's interest in religious freedom. Such barriers "could undermine public confidence in the (law society's) ability to regulate the public interest" according the the court.

item.title: Seventh Circuit upholds Chicago "bubble zone" abortion ordinance---HOLD
item.dc:creator: atomlinson
item.content:encoded:
A panel on the US Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit on Wednesday unanimously upheld the legality of a Chicago "bubble zone" ordinance, which prohibits any person from approaching within eight feet of another person near an abortion clinic with the purpose of engaging in sidewalk counseling without their consent. The panel, in deciding to uphold the ordinance, found it was indistinguishable from the Colorado law, which made it unlawful for any person within a hundred feet of a health care facility to knowingly approach within eight feet of another person to provide information pamphlets, protest, educate, or engage in sidewalk counseling without their consent, that was upheld by the Supreme Court in Hill v. Colorado in 2000. According to the panel, although recent Supreme Court rulings, such as Reed v. Town of Gilbert and McCullen v. Coakley, have weakened Hill's "foundation", contrary to the plaintiffs' argument, its ruling is still binding.
As [plaintiffs] see it, however, Hill is no longer an insuperable barrier to suits challenging abortion clinic bubble-zone laws. The premise of their claim is that the Court's more recent decisions in Reed and McCullen have so thoroughly undermined Hill's reasoning that we need not follow it. That's a losing argument in the court of appeals. The Court's intervening decisions have eroded Hill's foundation, but that case still binds us; only the Supreme Court can say otherwise. The Court's instructions in this situation are clear: "If a precedent of this Court has direct application in a case, yet appears to rest on reasons rejected in some other line of decisions, the Court of Appeals should follow the case [that] directly controls, leaving this Court the prerogative of overruling its own decisions."
The panel, essentially stating that at this level cannot provide the relief plaintiffs seek, urges plaintiffs to seek relief in the High Court.

item.title: Vermont lawmakers voice support for abortion bill---HOLD
item.dc:creator: tbrown
item.content:encoded: On Tuesday, the Vermont House voted 104-40 in favor of an abortion bill for the state. A final vote on the bill is scheduled for Thursday. The bill is known as H.57. It states that the intention of the bill is "to safeguard the right to abortion in Vermont by ensuring that right is not denied, restricted, or infringed by a governmental entity." The bill is similar to a law that was passed in New York earlier this year. Those who voted in favor of the bill noted that it does not change anything from current practice, but just ensures that women in Vermont will still retain the same rights. Opponents noted that the bill did not protect fetuses in the later stage of their development.

item.title: DOJ opposes request to prevent new development of fossil fuel infrastructure---HOLD
item.dc:creator: eslobe
item.content:encoded: The Environment and Natural Resources Division of the US Department of Justice (DOJ) submitted an opposition to motion for preliminary injunction on Tuesday in Juliana v. United States. The motion for preliminary injunction seeks to prevent the US from "authorizing through leases, permits, or other federal approvals: (1) mining or extraction of coal on Federal Public Lands; (2) offshore oil and gas exploration, development, or extraction on the Outer Continental Shelf; and (3) development of new fossil fuel infrastructure." In Juliana v. United States, 21 young plaintiffs filed a suit against the federal government arguing that the government's policies “deliberately allow[ed] atmospheric CO2 concentrations to escalate to levels unprecedented in human history.” The lawsuit argues that this has resulted in a "state-created danger." The case was originally filed in 2015. The DOJ argues that preliminary relief is not appropriate because the three-and-a-half year delay in filing the motion for preliminary relief shows that there is no irreparable harm that would exist without immediate relief. The DOJ also argues that the motion should be denied because the plaintiffs are not likely to succeed in their lawsuit. It is argued that the plaintiffs do not have standing to make the claim and they have not identified any "invasion of a legally protected interest that is concrete and particularized." The argument states that the plaintiffs fail to prove causation or establish that their injuries can be remedied by a court order. The plaintiffs are also argued to have not followed the appropriate procedures for the case because they did not follow the requirements of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA). The state-created danger is argued to be likely to fail because the claim fails to identify "an act by a government official that created an obvious, immediate, and particularized danger to a specific person known to that official." The lawsuit also ignores the acts from foreign actors. The irreparable harm is argued to not have been met because the amount of potential emissions before the resolution of the appeal would be "plainly de minimis" compared to the decades of emissions the suit argues is the source of their harm. It is also argued that an injunction would be against public interest due to the large number of jobs that would be lost. The Supreme Court allowed the case to continue through the court system in November.

item.title: US Supreme Court denies Florida tobacco companies' challenge to lawsuits--DNP
item.dc:creator: lmoffutt
item.content:encoded: The US Supreme Court on Monday denied review of two cases brought by Florida tobacco companies, leaving the companies exposed to potential liability in several cigarette lawsuits. Justice Kavanaugh recused himself from the case altogether.

item.title: Competing Federal Court injunctions block Trump admin rules allowing companies to deny free birth control to employees---HOLD
item.dc:creator: ofrance
item.content:encoded:
The Ninth Circuit partially blocked Trump administration rules which allowed companies to deny free contraceptives employees. The issue in question are the Affordable Care Act (ACA) regulations that require company group health plans to cover contraceptive care without cost sharing. The Trump administration's Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has issued rules that exempted employers with religious and moral objections from this requirement, causing several states to bring suit. The Ninth Circuit affirmed in part, vacated in part and remanded in part the U.S. District Court  for the Northern District of California's nationwide preliminary injunction against the new rules set to take effect January 14. The Ninth Circuit held that the plaintiffs did not have standing to bring such a suit because,
The district court’s preliminary injunction rested solely on its conclusion that the IFRs are likely to be procedurally invalid under the APA. If the final rules become effective as planned on January 14, there will be no justiciable controversy regarding the procedural defects of IFRs that no longer exist.
The court further went on to say, "The district court abused its discretion in granting a nationwide injunction." In it's opinion the court stated that they had concerns with nationwide injunctions and felt courts exercise prudence was necessary before issuing them. They cited the Supreme Court concerns that nationwide injunctions can have deferential consequences in the development of law and also deprive appellate courts of a wider range of perspectives. U.S. District Court Judge for the Eastern District Court of Pennsylvania also issued a nationwide injunction against the new rules as they went into effect. She stated that approximately 70,000 women would lose coverage putting them at risk for unwanted pregnancies.

item.title: 7th Circuit panel gives opponents to Chicago Airbnb law opportunity to prove standing in order to bring suit---HOLD
item.dc:creator: ofrance
item.content:encoded:
A three judge panel on for the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 7th Circuit vacated and remanded  United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Eastern Division's ruling that denied the opportunity of six named individuals and Keep Chicago Livable, the non-profit whose focus is on educating home-sharing hosts, to challenge whether Chicago’s Shared Housing Ordinance is constitutional. The 2016 ordinance was passed in order to regulate home-sharing by individuals through services like Airbnb and HomeAway. The District Court was instructed to make the determination as to whether the plaintiffs had standing. The issue for the court was whether the plaintiffs had standing to bring their suit. Did they each, or together, suffer an injury that was directly traceable to the 2016 Ordinance? Citing precedent the court stated,
We begin with the individual plaintiffs. While the amended complaint names six individuals as plaintiffs, the requisite standing inquiry—”an essential and unchanging part of the case-or-controversy requirement of Article III”— proceeds person-by-person. Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 560 (1992). Standing requires a threefold demonstration of “(1) an injury in-fact; (2) fairly traceable to the defendant’s action; and (3) capable of being redressed by a favorable decision from the court.” Pavrati Corp. v. City of Oak Forest, Ill., 630 F.3d 512, 516 (7th Cir. 2010) (citing Lujan, 504 U.S. at 560–61). The alleged injury must be not just “concrete and particularized,” but also “actual and imminent, not conjectural or hypothetical.” Lujan, 504 U.S. at 560; see also Spokeo, Inc. v. Robins, 136 S. Ct. 1540, 1547–48 (2016)
The named individuals, since filing their original complaint in 2016, had either ceased to live in Chicago, stopped visiting Chicago, no longer participating their home-sharing, or no longer living in buildings that were restricted, they claim all as a result of the Ordinance. Keep Chicago Livable on the other hand, has not shown through it's pleading that the organization itself, or any of it's members has suffered a direct injury that would give it the necessary standing under Article III. Judge Michael Scudder wrote in the opinion, “We have before us an organization and individuals with strongly-held views about the constitutionality of the City’s Ordinance, but Article III of the Constitution requires more: our authority is limited to deciding cases or controversies between adverse litigants, and without a clear indication that at least one named plaintiff has an actual or imminent injury, we have no authority to go further.

item.title: Leaked draft shows deliberation about family separation at the Mexican border
item.dc:creator: ssundier
item.content:encoded: A leaked 2017 draft of a family separation policy memo was released to the public on Friday by the office of Senator Jeff Markley. The draft, titled "Policy Options to Respond to Border Surge of Illegal Immigration," outlines and includes commentary about short term (30 day) and long term (6+ month) options for dealing with illegal immigrant families at the Mexican border. One of these comments specifically regards the expedited removal of unaccompanied alien children (UACs). If UACs are placed in the custody of Health and Human Services without a prior order of removal, then they have to go through "240 removal proceedings, which can be slow." The commentary instead suggests that Customs & Border Protection should place an expedited removal order on the entire family unit, so the Department of Homeland Security can "work with HHS to actually repatriate the minors." Another of these proposals seeks to increase the prosecutions of migrant parents at the southern border. This is consistent with the Trump Administration's "zero-tolerance policy," which sought to pursue the "prosecution of certain criminal immigration offenses." Cumulatively, these initiatives were intended to attract media coverage to generate a "substantial deterrent effect." This document follows the recent report that potentially thousands more immigrant children were separated from their families at the border than previously reported.

item.title: Solicitor General asks Supreme Court to decide Federal Judge ruling against immigration census question---HOLD
item.dc:creator: ofrance
item.content:encoded: United States Solicitor General Noel Francisco asked the Supreme Court to decide if the immigration question that was re-inserted into the census by Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross is lawful. U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York, Judge Jesse Furman, ruled that the commerce secretary's insertion of the question into the census was arbitrary and capricious and a violation of the Administrative Procedures Act (APA). The APA guides how Federal Agencies promulgate rules and regulations. Secretary Ross said the question was re-inserted at the requested at the behest of the Justice Department in their furtherance of better enforcing the Voting Rights Act. This move by the Solicitor General is an unusual end-around the normal procedure of appealing the case to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit first. This was done because there may not be enough time for both the Second Circuit and the Supreme Court to both review it, as the census must be finalized by the end of June 2019 in order for it to be printed on time.

item.title: Zimbabwe Human Rights Commission says security forces tortured protesters---HOLD
item.dc:creator: mborges
item.content:encoded: The Zimbabwe Human Rights Commission (ZHRC) on Tuesday said "security forces instigated systematic torture of residents following" last week's violent fuel price protests. The ZHRC says the high levels of force used against those protesters who were injured or killed suggests police brutality. Police have the death toll at three but others say there were at least a dozen deaths. President Emmerson Mnangagwa has said this brutality is "unacceptable and a betrayal." While calling for a dialogue between both sides, the President said that even though everyone has the right to peacefully protest, this was not a peaceful one. The Zimbabwe government recently more than doubled fuel prices in response to shortages and illegal fuel trading. The local currency, called "bollars", is set to be equal to the US dollar but is being sold on the black market for much less; this incentivizes black market fuel trading as a much cheaper way to get fuel. Zimbabwe now faces a low supply of USD and low confidence in the bollar. Their economy is struggling with high inflation and stagnated wages. Meanwhile, domestic companies are not able to satisfy consumer demand and the country is struggling to pay for its imports.

item.title: Former WV Supreme Court Chief Justice Sentenced to 24-months Federal Prison---HOLD
item.dc:creator: mbarber
item.content:encoded: Former West Virginia Supreme Court Chief Justice, Allen Loughry, was sentenced to 24-months in Federal prison on Wednesday. Loughry, who authored a book about political corruption in WV and resigned in November, was found guilty on 10 federal charges including wire fraud and mail fraud. The various charges originated from the misuse of state credit cards and vehicles for personal travel, lying to federal agents, and most notably from having a state-owned antique desk removed from the capitol building to his private home.  Judge John Thomas Copenhaver Jr. delivered the 24-month sentence, which exceeded the recommended range of 10-16 months due to special considerations, but placed Loughry on 3-years supervised release, and ordered restitution in the amount of $1,273 and a $10,000 fine (top be paid within 60 days). S.D.W.Va._2_18-cr-00134_139_0

item.title: Seven UK lawmakers quit Labour Party citing Brexit 'betrayal' and anti-Semitism---HOLD
item.dc:creator: mbarber
item.content:encoded: In a press conference and with only 39 days left until Britain is set to leave the EU seven lawmakers resigned from the Labour Party on Monday citing disagreement with leader Jeremy Corbyn's approach to Brexit in addition to a failure to address anti-Semitism within the party. Among the seven lawmakers, now calling themselves the "Independent Group," are Chris Leslie, Luciana Berger, Angela Smith, Gavin Shuker, Chuka Umunna, Mike Gapes and Ann Coffey. The group will continue to sit as members of Parliament and now seeks to build new coalitions. The group claims that "none of today’s political parties are fit to provide the leadership and direction needed by [the UK]," in a statement released on their website. Chris Leslie, separately released a statement through Twitter, detailing his reasons for his departure after more than 30-years as a Labour Party member. Leslie noted among his reasons was that the Labour Party he knew has been "hijacked by the machine politics of the hard left."  Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn expressed disappointment with the MPs exits in a statement while referencing "the Labour policies that inspired millions at the last election" which increased Labour Party representation "by the largest share since 1945." In a video message, Labour Party Deputy Leader Tom Watson described the departure as "premature" and cautioned members from falling into "a virulent form of identity politics [which] has seized the Labour Party." Watson went on to characterize the resignations as "a wakeup call" to the problem of anti-Semitism within the party. A problem which the Party has been "slow to acknowledge" and "even slower to deal with." Watson closes with a message to remaining party members declaring, "[w]e need to broaden out so that all the members of our broad church feel welcome in our congregation."

item.title: TEST - Vermont Supreme Court Rules Truancy Not Educational Neglect For Some Students
item.dc:creator: tmaalouf
item.content:encoded: The Vermont Supreme Court has ruled that truancy alone does not satisfy the state's requirement for adjudicating a child "in need of care or supervision" if the child is not of school age. Under Vermont law, a child may be adjudicated "in need of care or supervision" (CHINS) if the child is "habitually and without justification truant from compulsory school attendance" or is without educational care "necessary for his or her well-being". The mother of three children adjudicated CHINS challenged the state's argument that all three children were CHINS, not because of their absences alone, but that "given their needs" the absences constituted educational neglect. The Vermont Supreme Court found that the oldest child was correctly adjudicated because she was required by law to attend school but that the two younger children could not be similarly adjudicated because they were not required to attend.  In cases where school attendance is not compulsory, the state must prove by the preponderance of the evidence that a student's absences constitute educational neglect by creating a risk of harm to the her well-being which the state failed to do.

item.title: TEST: Georgia Supreme Court states that a driver's refusal to not have their breath tested isn't evidence of a DUI
item.dc:creator: kboyle
item.content:encoded: The Supreme Court of Georgia struck down parts of Georgia statutory law that allow a person’s refusal to submit to a breath test when pulled over for a DUI to be used as evidence in the driver’s trial. Georgia law requires people who are pulled over by the authorities to submit to tests that to determine if you are under the influence of alcohol. If you refuse to participate in this test, your Georgia driver’s license will be taken away for one year. The Supreme Court of Georgia found the state’s original DUI law goes against article I of the Georgia Constitution’s protections from self-incrimination. The court was faced with this issue in regards to one of its residents, Andrea Elliot, who was being prosecuted by the state for driving under the influence of alcohol. The court referenced a previous case from 2017 entitled Olevik v. State, with a court ruling that prevented the state from forcing chemical breath tests upon suspected drunk drivers. The court here also cited extensively to the evolution of American Law in regards to the right one has against self-incrimination. The court specific that paragraph XVI of Georgia 1983 Constitution applies more regularly than the 1877 provision regarding one's right against self-incrimination. Justice Peterson, writing for the court, acknowledged that, "the State has a considerable interest in prosecuting DUI offenses (and thereby deterring others), and that our decision today may make that task more difficult." He further clarified that "the right to be free from compelled self-incrimination does not wax or wane based on the severity of a defendant's alleged crimes." The court further stressed the importance of applying old law to current matters, "Although the text of the 1877 Provision considered in isolation does not clearly preclude admission of evidence that a defendant refused a breath test, that does not end our analysis of the provision’s meaning." The court further stated that it did not have the power to rewrite statutes. This power, they state, was reserved for the General Assembly. The court concluded that "OCGA §§ 40-5-67.1 (b) and 40-6-392 (d) are unconstitutional to the extent that they allow a defendant’s refusal to submit to a breath test to be admitted into evidence at a criminal trial."

item.title: TEST: Circuit judge struck down West Virginia right-to-work law
item.dc:creator: ywang
item.content:encoded: Judge Jennifer F. Bailey on Wednesday issued a circuit court opinion striking down key components of West Virginia's 2016 right-to-work law, which banned union fee collection. The law, commonly referred to as the "Workplace Freedom Act", amended West Virginia's existing Labor Management Relations Act of 1971 (LMRA) in two aspects: (1) employees covered by a collective bargaining contract are no longer required to join the union, and (2) employees can refrain from paying agency fees to the union. The Court ordered these amendments to be declared violative of West Virginia's Constitution and have no force and effect as law. The unions sued West Virginia Governor James C. Justice and Attorney General Patrick Morrisey in their official capacity. The issue before the circuit court was whether the 2016 legislation's ban on agency fees was constitutional. The Court noted that although there were precedents from other States that upheld similar fee bans, this Court was only bound by US Supreme Court precedents, and they have never addressed or upheld a ban on agency fees for private sector unions. The Court first addressed the unions' rights of association, and held that the legislation violated the right as protected by Art. III, §§ 7 and 16 of the West Virginia Constitution. The unions were not forcing any association, the court held, instead they were collecting fees that "essentially function as taxes on collective bargaining members for the cost of 'legislative' and governmental services". The Court next held that the legislation was an unconstitutional taking of property, because it essentially took the money from the union (and its members) and gave it to the free riders (non-members who were not paying agency fees). If the legislation came into force, employees would get the union's service without any cost, thus giving them no incentive to join the union or remain a member.

item.title: Federal court strikes down West Virginia right-to-work law---HOLD
item.dc:creator: chsu
item.content:encoded: On Thursday, the Circuit Court of Kanahwa County, West Virginia struck down a portion of the state's right-to-work law. The suit concerned West Virginia's Workplace Freedom Act that was passed in 2016. The court noted the act, (aka "Senate Bill 1/SB-1") itself, was a "right-to-work" law. The act came in the form of an amendment that effectively eliminated the requirement that a) workers join labor unions, and b) pay dues to labor unions. The court noted that such labor unions, as a condition of their function, still continued to represent non-card carrying, as long as said workers are working within the unions' industries, despite the workers not paying membership dues. The amendment also criminalizes any violation with criminal or civil penalties. The Circuit Court began with a background discussion of the federal National Labor Relations Act of 1935 (NLRA). As a an aftershock of the labor abuses and rampant economic inequalities which culminated with the Great Depression, the NLRA guaranteed workers across the nation the right to unionize and be represented during collective bargaining disputes with their employers. The later Taft-Hartley Act of 1947 would cut away at the protections set by the NLRA. Taft-Hartley prohibited workers from being required to join unions. The Circuit Court noted that the Taft-Hartley Act formed the precedent authority behind West Virginia's SB-1 Amendment. The court elected not to address SB-1's first provision. It noted that the plaintiffs argued that it was not justified that unions continue to represent workers of an entire industry, and yet those same workers be allowed to benefit from union services without having to pay fees. Ultimately, the court left the provision banning any requirement for workers to join unions, intact. At the same time, the court struck the state's prohibition of employment contracts that require workers to pay for the union services they benefit from. The message the court may have sent to West Virginian workers would be that if workers don't want to join, then they don't have to. But if they want the benefits provided by labor unions, then they should pay for it.

item.title: Former Egyptian anti-corruption watchdog looses bid for freedom after court upholds 5-year jail term---HOLD
item.dc:creator: ofrance
item.content:encoded: Egypt's former chief auditor, Hisham Geneina, lost his bid for freedom after charges that he spread false news about the armed forces and the country's internal affairs resulted in his being sentenced by the country's military court in April 2018 to five years in prison. The military court upheld his conviction. Geneina was first arrested in February 2018 after an interview he gave to HuffPost online in which he claimed his former boss, former military chief of staff Sami Anan, had secret documents abroad that would implicate the military and the country's leadership in a corruption scheme that cost the country Billions of dollars. Geneina  himself had run the presidential campaign of Anan, who himself was subsequently arrested by the military of running for office without permission. Genena can still has another opportunity to challenge his conviction at Egypt's highest military court of appeals.

item.title: Wells Fargo reaches $240 million settlement with US shareholders---HOLD
item.dc:creator: lmoffutt
item.content:encoded: Wells Fargo & Co. agreed to pay $240 million to US shareholders late Thursday to settle claims under the Securities Exchange Act stemming from Wells Fargo employees creating fake, unauthorized accounts. The lawsuit accused 20 current or former Wells Fargo officer and directors of a breach of fiduciary duty, saying they "knew or consciously disregarded that the Company’s employees were illicitly creating millions of customer accounts without those customers’ knowledge or consent."  The $240 million cash settlement will be paid by Wells Fargo's insurers, thereby making this the largest "insurer-funded" recovery in a shareholder derivative action. Since the lawsuit was initiated nearly two years ago, Wells Fargo has made several remedial changes, including: "changes top-level management and the composition of the Board, new and improved internal controls, a stronger risk management framework, expanded monitoring of Company culture, and enhanced oversight functions." The parties will await final court approval at the settlement hearing.

item.title: Carlos Ghosn granted bail by Tokyo Court which rejected prosecutors request---HOLD
item.dc:creator: ofrance
item.content:encoded: After 107 days of detention in a Japanese jail, Carlos Ghosn, the former Nissan-Renault chief was granted a ¥1 billion, equivalent to almost $9 million by a Japanese court, in what some consider a rare move, by going against the wishes of the Tokyo District Public Prosecutor’s Office special investigation unit. Credited for Mr. Ghosn's release is his new legal team led by Mr. Junichiro Hironaka, whose nickname is "Razor," which is based on his keen legal mind, and has garnered him a reputation of being able to successfully defend of high-profile clients. Mr. Hironaka has won not-guilty verdicts in some of the country’s most high-profile cases and believes Mr. Ghosn is innocent based on their interactions and his “gut feeling.” In a statement, Mr. Ghosn expressed his gratitude to friends and family and vowed to fight the merit-less charges against him.

item.title: Washington Senate approves bill to end use of coal by 2025---HOLD
item.dc:creator: eslobe
item.content:encoded: The Washington Senate passed SB 5116 on Friday with a vote of 28-19. The bill will require all electric utilities to end the use of coal-fired resources from their electricity generation by December 31, 2025. The House Committee on Environment and Energy held a public hearing on the bill on Tuesday. The bill declares that ending the use of coal energy in the state is necessary to address the impacts of climate change. The bill also requires the state's electricity supply to become carbon-neutral by 2030 and carbon-free by 2045. Utilities will be able to recover the costs of the early retirements through their rates. The law specifically prohibits the use of new diversions, new impoundments, new bypass reaches, or expansion of existing reservoirs for hydroelectric generation unless they are used for pumped storage facilities that meet fish recovery plans and all laws and regulations. Existing hydroelectric facilities can still undergo efficiency or other improvements. Hydroelectric facilities can also be installed in man-made waterways as long as the comply with fish recovery plans and all laws and regulations. Any utility who continues to use coal energy after December 31, 2025, will be fine $60 per MW-h of electricity generation. The penalty will be adjusted every two years based on inflation. Starting in 2040, the commission can increase the fee if doing so will accelerate compliance. A utility can also petition to be relieved of paying the penalty if it shows that compliance would compromise power quality or its obligation to meet electricity reliability standards. Utilities will also be exempt from paying the fee if the Governor declares an energy emergency. Fees collected under the bill will be used for low-income weatherization and structural rehabilitation assistance. The new bill follows Oregon who signed a law in March 2016 to end the use of coal from its power supply by 2030. Last month, a court in Australia also refused to allow the development of a new coal mine due to climate change concerns.

item.dc:creator: rmoore

item.title: Washington senate passes bill restricting child vaccination exemptions---HOLD
item.dc:creator: chsu
item.content:encoded: The Washington state House passed a bill that would remove the option allowing parents of schoolchildren from electing to exempt their children from receiving mandatory vaccinations on the philosophical or personal grounds. The bill initiative came in reaction to the recent up-tick in measles outbreaks within the state. It aims to promote immunization to 95% of the population. Children's families must provide proof of immunization from chickenpox, diphtheria, measles, German measles, haemophilus influenza type B disease, hepatitis B, mumps, pneumococcal disease, polio, tetanus, and whooping cough. Currently, Washington state law allows families of children to opt out of vaccinations if the families provide proof that children have a) adverse reactions to vaccination b) philosophical or personal objections to vaccination, or c) religious objections. The bill removes the ability of families to claim exemption from vaccination based on philosophical or personal reasons. The bill's language appears to elucidate the requirements regarding children or their family's adverse reactions to vaccinations. It also appears to leave the religious exemption intact as well. Opponents of the amendment cite the dangers of immunization, including the possibility of encephalitis and even death. The bill is currently set for further deliberation on the state Senate floor.

item.title: California non-profit urges ICC to investigate Syria rights abuses---HOLD
item.dc:creator: atomlinson
item.content:encoded: The Guernica Centre for International Justice (TGG) urged the International Criminal Court (ICC) to conduct a preliminary investigation into human right abuses committed by officials in Syria against its citizens, asserting that the ICC may have jurisdiction to conduct such an investigation despite Syria's non-membership. According to Toby Cadman, co-founder of TGG and international human rights lawyer, a precedent put forth in 2018, involving Rohingya crisis in Myanmar, can be applied to grant the ICC jurisdiction over some portion of the issues in Syria. In that case, ICC judges held that because Muslim Rohingya people were driven from Myanmar into Bangladesh, a country that is a member of the ICC, the court had jurisdiction. Similarly, according to Cadman, the atrocities committed by Syria, which forced millions of civilians into Jordan, a member of the ICC, lends to the ICC asserting jurisdiction. Earlier this month, the TGG filed an investigative report with the ICC regarding forced deportation in Syria, supplemented by evidence against the Syrian officials who conspired to enforce such practices. The TGG allege that Syria's lack of membership in the ICC has enabled its President Bashar Al Assad, and his regime, to not be held accountability for "atrocities enacted during the country's bloody civil war." The ICC is currently reviewing the documents sent by the TGG.

item.title: Philippine Appeals Court found news site critical of President Duterte violated a constitutional ban on foreign ownership---HOLD
item.dc:creator: ofrance
item.content:encoded: The Philippine Appeals Court found that online news site Rappler, Inc. violated the Philippine constitutional ban on foreign ownership by allowing it's U.S. investor, Omidyar Network to engage in decision making at the corporate level as well as editorially. Filipino news outlets are constitutionally required to be completely owned and managed by Filipinos. Rappler has been critical of Filipino President Rodrigo Duterte in its coverage and has come under increased scrutiny by the government. Rapplers CEO and executive editor, Maria Ressa has had charges of cyber libel filed against her, by the Filipino Department of Justice (DOJ), for a story written in May 2012. The cyber libel law that was violated was enacted 4 months after the alleged cyber libel took place. The complaint was later dismissed by the National Bureau of Investigation's Cyber-crime Division, because the one-year statute of limitations for the filing of libel had lapsed. Maria Ressa is also facing tax-evasion charges brought against her by the DOJ. Maria Ressa has refuted all charges against her, and has previously stated that she believes "the law has been weaponized against her." The Philippine Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) revoked the websites license after its investigation found that Rappler may have violated nationality restrictions on ownership and control of mass media outlets. The Omidyar Network donated its holdings to the management and staff of the Rappler and the Appeals Court asked the SEC to reassess its decision to revoke the organizations license in view of this new information.

item.title: Environmental advocates win suit against the Bureau of Land Management---HOLD
item.dc:creator: chsu
item.content:encoded: This week, the environmental advocacy community won its first victory against the recent wave of environmental regulatory drawbacks by the federal government. The case was brought by two environmental advocacy groups, "WildEarth Guardians" and "Physicians for Social Responsibility". The defendant federal regulatory agency was the U.S. Bureau of Land Management (BLM). The BLM is an agency responsible for managing the nation's lands and a portion of its mineral resources. The BLM is under the umbrella of the larger federal agency, the Department of the Interior. There were also three petroleum companies that intervened as co-defendants in this case. Notably, this marks the first time a federal judge ruled on an environmental regulatory issue following the dialing-back trend of federal government regulatory environmental policies under the Trump administration. The federal court analyzed the actions of BLM based on the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA). The NEPA was enacted in 1970 for the purpose of requiring federal agencies to be more mindful of what its actions might have on the environment. Most notably, 42 U.S.C. § 4332 (C) of NEPA requires most federal agencies whose activities are likely to affect the quality of the environment to produce an "environmental impact statement" (EIS) prior to implementing any projects or actions. Federal law authorizes the BLM to plan for development of federal land. It also authorizes the BLM to lease the land, as well as approve permits authorizing oil companies to drill on said land. The plaintiffs argue that the BLM failed to diligently take into consideration environmental implications when it leased the land to oil companies. Plaintiffs asked the court to void the land leases issued by the BLM to the oil companies. The Court ruled that the BLM did, indeed, fail to take into account certain greenhouse gas emission contingencies into its environmental impact analysis/statement prior to issuing out its land lease to the oil companies. It, however, declined to void the entire land lease, but stated that the court will continue to hold jurisdictional oversight over this matter and the BLM until the BLM reconsiders its environmental impact analysis, and produces an EIS in accordance with the requirements of NEPA.

item.title: Test - Human Rights Watch accuses DRC police of 'disappearing' 34 youth
item.dc:creator: tmaalouf
item.content:encoded: Human Rights Watch (HRW) on Thursday released a report accusing police in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) of carrying out a campaign of abduction, murder and 'forced disappearance' against alleged gang members. The first Operation Likofi in 2013 resulted in the death of 51 young men and boys and the investigation of the commander of the police's Anti-Crime Campaign. The campaign, called "Operation Likofi IV" is the latest in a series of police operations targeting suspected gang members referred to as "kulunas" in the capital city of Kinshasa.  At least 27 kulunas were executed and 7 others forcibly disappeared in the latest round of operations.  Among the dead were three boys ages 15 to 17.  A senior security official told HRW that among the targets of Operation Likofi IV were kanlunas involved in opposition demonstrations.  The DRC has a history of repressing pro-democracy demonstrations and in early August of 2018 police used live ammunition and tear gas to disperse a group protesting against the government. General Kasongo, the Kinshasa police commissioner, officially denied the existence of Operation Likofi IV in a phone conversation with HRW on December 11 saying, “Since I’ve been in charge, we haven’t done an Operation Likofi . . . If we arrest kulunas, we send them to justice. The police I command aren’t involved in any operation to kill kulunas. We’re republican police, we need to respect human rights, only God can kill someone.”  But a Kinshasa police officer resported that Gen. Kasongo told officers in a meeting that the kulunas needed to "disappear" and another security services officer suggested that the operation was designed to suppress youth voters: "They targeted the leaders, who are known and who mobilize other young people. Fear had to be created to prevent them from responding to calls to demonstrate in the run-up to the elections." Félix Tshisekedi won the disputed December elections with 34.7% of the vote.  Emmanuel Shadary, the prior president, came in third with 23.8%.

item.title: Test - Congolese Police Accused of Execution During Abusive Anti-Crime Campaign in 2018
item.dc:creator: ywang
item.content:encoded: Human Rights Watch posted a report on February 21 about Congolese Police operation summarily executing at least 27 people and forcibly disappearing 7 others between May and September 2018 in Congo’s capital, Kinshasa. According to the report, the operation is known as “Operation Likofi IV”, during which the police would apprehend suspected gang members known as kulunas at night from their homes or other locations. In some cases, the police would blindfold, bound and took the suspect to unknown locations before strangling them. Kulunas were responsible for serious crimes, including armed robbery and violent assaults, in Kinshasa.  Operation Likofi IV began after the vice prime minister and interior and security minister Henri Mova's proposal of a national plan on April 10 to fight urban criminality, with a plan to eliminate the "kuluna phenomenon". The government said that one objective of Operation Likofi IV was to spread fear and deter protests to the December elections. From November 2013 to February 2014, the first Operation Likofi included the summary executions of at least 51 people and the forced disappearance of 33 others. Human Rights Watch interviewed about 80 people, including family members of the victims, medical and social workers, activists and government officials from Kinshasa regarding the executions and forced disappearances during Operation Likofi IV. Three of the victims killed ages 16 and 17. One disappeared boy ages 15. Interviewees said that the victims were unarmed and posed no imminent risk to life that justified the use of lethal force. Police officers and one social worker said that many police officers involved in the operation came from the Anti-Criminal Police of Kinshasa province. Police accounts link General Kasongo, Kinshasa’s police commissioner, to the Likofi IV operations. A social worker suggested that the operation was targeted at the young people who were not siding with authorities for the upcoming elections, who wanted to use the operation to spread fear.  In a phone conversation with Human Rights Watch on December 11, 2018, General Kasongo denied the existence of any police operation targeting gang members. “Since I’ve been in charge, we haven’t done an Operation Likofi,” he said. “If we arrest kulunas, we send them to justice. The police I command aren’t involved in any operation to kill kulunas. We’re republican police, we need to respect human rights, only God can kill someone.” Vice prime minister Henri Mova, in a phone conversation with Human Rights Watch on December 18, 2018, called the allegations "absurd". The new president of Congo, Félix Tshisekedi, came in office on January 24, 2019 after a disputed election.  Deputy Africa director at Human Rights Watch Ida Sawyer urged Congo's new administration to “put an end to abusive police campaigns and work to ensure that those responsible for these horrific crimes are investigated and prosecuted.” Human Rights Watch expects that the new administration "suspend from office any government or security force official credibly implicated in extrajudicial killings or enforced disappearances pending a thorough, fair, and impartial investigation".

item.title: Democratic Republic of Congo has Crackdown on Safety
item.dc:creator: pdewitt
item.content:encoded:
Lack of accountability arising from government-sponsored crackdowns on dissidents and outliers in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The reported summary execution program's very deplorability is contested by police commissioner of Kinshasa, D Gen. Sylvano Kasongo; though, however, under the guise of Operation Likofi, in its fifth brand: Likofi IV, from the initial start of phase one in 2013, with 51 confirmed summary executions of young men targeted as kalunas/suspected gang members, with 31 others missing from November 2013 to February 2014. Now, security forces have killed, without trial, 27 kalunas and 7 more are reportedly missing, between May through September 2018 that premiering President Felix Tshisekedi hopes to end as with all human rights abuses"based on interviews with nearly 80 witnesses, victims' family members, (and) security officials('s)" report. Far from being reminiscent of the 1960 declaration by President Kasavubu and Prime Minister of Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC)... though martial law was declared for six months following the separation from Belgium, history shows it was to boast M. Lumumba's political strength, to the Congo and United Nations. Thus, in a way, there are similarities in the power grab that can be found through any election. The DRC tactics produce violent force, though the liability rests on U.N. rights experts, whether it is when the police arrest political opponents and kill a party member, as on September 1st, 2018, or 65 protesting people, as occurred two days later, but must shift to the establishment. "State and Corporate Accountability in the Democratic Republic of Congo" of the demands in Institute for Human Rights and Development and Others v. Democratic Republic of Congo (Case number: Communication 393/10) claim 3 International Network for Economic, Social and Cultural Rights members against "Rights and Accountability in Development" ("RAID"), "Action Contre l’Inpunite pour les Droits de l’homme" ("ACIDH"), and the "Institute for Human Rights & Development in Africa" ("IHRDA"):
"the violent attacks, and the ensuing 13-year legal battle for justice, is indicative of a continuing need to put in place a comprehensive international legal framework on corporate accountability, in order to clarify state obligations (including extraterritorial) in the regulation of corporate activities and remove barriers to justice. Towards this end, ESCR-Net members and allies are working collectively to advocate for a strong UN treaty to prevent and remedy human rights abuses by or associated with the actions of transnational corporations and other companies."
It is only through a strong push to demand accountability through the courts that the Democratic Republic of Congo will begin to reign in its use of summary execution, to the upmost imperative as defined by law, whether in war, opposition, or upheaval.

item.title: TEST Judge Grants Citizenship to Both Twin Sons of a Gay Couple
item.dc:creator: kboyle
item.content:encoded: The California federal Court on Thursday ruled that a twin son, who was a child of a gay married couple is considered an American citizen since birth. The parents of the twin boys, Andrew and Elad Dvash-Banks were seeking the same rights for Ethan as for his brother Aidan, who was deemed a citizen. Judge John F. Walter found that U.S. law does not demand that a child must have a biological relationship with their parents to gain citizenship, if their parents were married to their birth. Andrew Dvash-Banks was studying in Israel when he met his husband, Elad, an Israeli citizen. They moved to Canada, where they were married in 2010. The children were born by means of a surrogate in September 2016. This decision is important for LGBTQ rights internationally, as it is a pivotal decision which grants sam-sex couples the same adoptive rights as others in regard to their children's citizenship.

item.title: TEST
item.dc:creator: kboyle
item.content:encoded: On February 22, 2019 the District Court of the South District decided that it is unconstitutional to have an all male military draft. The court determined that the male only registration requirement was not "substantially related" to Congress' objective of governing and maintaining effective armed forces. They further ruled that the draft was based on "archaic" generalizations about the preferences and abilities of women. The court here spoke further on the development of women's role within our country's military. They stated that men and women are of equal capabilities and that is being recognized in our more equal society. They further stated that men and women are now "similarly situation for the purposes fo a draft or registration for a draft" Finally, the court nullified the defendant's argument regarding female leave from motherhood. They addressed this misconception by stating that a woman fighting in combat does not pose a problem for any direct objective of Congress.

item.title: TEST D.C. district court rejects challenge to ban on bump stocks
item.dc:creator: ywang
item.content:encoded: D.C. district court denied motions for preliminary injunction on Monday against a rule by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives (ATF). The rule amends the definition of "machinegun" under the National Firearms Act of 1934 (NFA) to include bump stocks and will become effective in March. The President and Congress urged ATF to rule in response to the mass shooting in Las Vegas that killed 58 people. Plaintiffs contended that when promulgating the rule, (1) ATF violated Administrative Procedure Act (APA); (2) the rule violated the Takings Clause of the Fifth Amendment; (3) then-Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker lacked authority either under the Appointments Clause or 28 U.S.C. § 508 (the AG Act). The court disagreed with the plaintiffs. First, the court adopted Chevron doctrine in rejecting the administrative law arguments. NFA defines "machinegun" as devices that permit a firearm to shoot “automatically more than one shot, without manual reloading, by a single function of the trigger” 26 U.S.C. § 5845(b). Since “single function of the trigger” and “automatically” are not further defined, ATF was permitted to reasonably interpret them. Second, regarding the Takings Clause challenge, plaintiffs failed to show why a preliminary injunction was better than future compensation. Third, regarding Whitaker's authority, the President has discretion to appoint under the Federal Vacancies Reform Act (FVRA) to change AG Act's line of succession. The court also followed Supreme Court precedent and historical practice to allow temporary service by non-Senate confirmed officials, as in this case.

item.title: TEST - District Court and Federal Order Urges Ban on Bump-Stocks
item.dc:creator: pdewitt
item.content:encoded:
Fortune reports, February 26th, 2019 resultant from a December 18, 2018 article: a definitive Trump ban on bump-stocks emerged, following a Department of Justice final order changing law on the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives (ATF), pursuant to the outcome of Guedes v. Bureau of Alcohol, a subsequent denial of the petition on January 25, 2019, denying claims against the order's demand to ban "bump fire" stocks. ATF defines these stocks as elaborating upon December 18th, when Acting Attorney General Whitaker announced that "bump stocks" equate to "machineguns", initiating a new federal rule that bans "continuous firing cycle with a single pull of the trigger." Fortune claims the report projects disbelief at the October 1, 2017 Las Vegas shooting, and focuses on the attached bump-stock device, reflexive of a Fortune November 29, 2018 reporting of Trumps promise to ban bump stocks. In the case of Guedes v. Bureau of Alcohol, Judge Dabney L. Friedrich opened the memorandum opinion, denying the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction by means of historical comparison to the Vegas shooting. The rationality behind urging the courts to reconsider the National Firearms Act of 1934 is considering the inclusion of preventative inclusion of "bump-stock type devises" in all regulatory affairs of machine guns. The plaintiff, Guedes, of the Firearms Policy Coalition and others claimed a violation of  the Vacrancy law in 28 U.S.C. § 508 and Guedes brought about complaint over 18 U.S.C. § 926(b), allocating "the agency rulemaking authority", as well as the "Takings Clause of the Fifth Amendment" regarding current legal possessors. The Washington D.C. District Court found the overarching theme to be undermined by the Chevron document, which permits the reasonably definition of statutory terms by the agency. The court declination of the petition, and all associated challenges of power, read throughout Guedes v. Bureau of Alcohol,:
“[T]he court, as well [as] the agency, must give effect to the unambiguously expressed intent of Congress.” Lubow v. U.S. Dep’t of State, 783 F.3d 877, 884 (D.C. Cir. 2015) (quoting Chevron, 467 U.S. at 842–43). But if the text is silent or ambiguous, courts must “determine if the agency’s interpretation is permissible, and if so, defer to it.” Confederated Tribes of Grand Ronde Cmty., 830 F.3d at 558. “This inquiry, often called Chevron Step Two, does not require the best interpretation, only a reasonable one.”
In Chevron v. Nat. Res. Def. Council, machine gun is defined in both plain language and to statutory efficacy, and as described, the interpretation of the current law addressing the need for gun control is found in the Chevron deference, as is addressed by The Honorable Antonin Scalia. The current federal code is to be installed in March, 90 days from the reasonable order for a new federal law banning bump stocks.

item.title: TEST Federal court rejects ban on bump stocks
item.dc:creator: gpaschke
item.content:encoded: On Monday, Judge Friedrich for the United States District Court of the District of Columbia struck down challenges to a rule promulgated by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives ("ATF") which effectively bans bump-stock devices.  The rule is expected to go into effect on March 26, 2019. The rule, passed in the wake of the Las Vegas mass shooting which left 58 people dead and hundreds wounded, broadens the ATF's definition of "machine gun to include bump-stock-type devices."  The agency's authorization stems from the Firearms Owners’ Protection Act of 1986 (FOPA). The plaintiffs, in a motion for preliminary injunction, raised three challenges to the rule. They asserted that the ATF violated the American Procedural Act by failing to meet the standards set out in the Chevron doctrine. In addition, the plaintiffs argued that the rule violates the taking clause by forcing bump-stock owners to destroy or abandon property without compensation. Their final challenge pressed on the constitutional and statutory authority of then-acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker. The court held, "the plaintiffs have not met their burden of showing entitlement to a preliminary injunction." The court reasoned that the likelihood of the claims' success on the merits was not sufficient to grant a preliminary injunction.

item.title: TEST Federal court dismissed suit against actor James Woods
item.dc:creator: gpaschke
item.content:encoded:
The US Court of Appeals for the 6th circuit, on Wednesday, dismissed a defamation and invasion of privacy lawsuit against James Woods, a famous actor, despite denying Wood’s motion which claimed Portia Boulger, the appellant, failed to meet procedural requirements. On March 12, 2016, the day after a presidential candidate Donald Trump rally in Chicago, Illinois, a photo circulated depicting a woman wearing a Trump shirt, and giving a Nazi salute. After misidentifying Boulger, Twitter handle @voxday captioned the photo with “The ‘Trump Nazi’ is Portia Boulger, who runs the Women for Bernie Sanders Twitter account. It’s another media plant.” Woods retweeted the photo with the additional comment “So-called #Trump ‘Nazi’ is a #BernieSanders agitator/operative?” Later that same day, multiple other news outlets appropriately identified the women in the photo, however, Woods failed to delete his tweet for 11 days. Boulger said in that 11day period she “received hundreds of obscene and threatening messages, including death threats, as well as numerous telephone calls.” On March 3, 2017, she filed a suit against Woods, alleging “defamation and invasion of privacy under Ohio law.”  In the complaint, Boulger stated that as a result of Woods’s tweet, she suffered “severe emotional distress including sleeplessness, episodes of reasonable apprehension of personal assault or attack, anxiety and depression.”   On the substantive issue, the court held that Woods was not liable under Ohio’s innocent construction rule.
Under the rule, a statement reasonably susceptible to both a defamatory and an innocent meaning must be construed, as a matter of law, to have an innocent meaning. It matters not that the defamatory meaning is the more obvious one. So long as the statement may reasonably be read to have an innocent meaning, the innocent construction rule commands that the statement be deemed non-defamatory.
The court stated Wood’s tweet could be understood as Woods "merely asking" his followers a question and since it "could be reasonably read to have an innocent meaning" the claim, "as a matter of law, is not actionable." The court also addressed Woods’s cross claim that Boulger, as a procedural matter, failed to properly serve him in a timely matter. The court dismissed Wood’s claim in stating “Woods waived his jurisdictional defenses through his conduct.”

item.title: Test: Fazaga v. Walls
item.dc:creator: kboyle
item.content:encoded: The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals judges Thursday issued a ruling originating from a claim of illegal surveillance at Orange County mosques. The court stated that the government could not hide behind their state secrets privilege in order to deny a lawsuit brought by the ACLU. "The legal questions presented in this case have been many and difficult," the judges wrote in the ruling. "Dismissing claims based on the privilege where the Government has expressly told the court it is not necessary to do so—and, in particular, invoking the privilege to dismiss, at the pleading stage, claims the Government has expressly told the court it need not dismiss on grounds of privilege—cuts directly against Jeppesen’s call for careful, limited application of the privilege." The 9th Circuit said  that the district court should  have determined whether their electronic surveillance of the the mosque was “lawfully authorized and conducted” and whether it violated the members of the mosque's constitutional rights. "In holding, for the reasons stated, that the Government’s assertion of the state secrets privilege does not warrant dismissal of this litigation in its entirety, we, too, have recognized the need for balance, but also have heeded the conclusion at the heart of Congress’s enactment of FISA: the fundamental principles of liberty include devising means of forwarding accountability while assuring national security." This ruling represents a move towards governmental accountability and progress. The 9th circuit's reviewal of this case showcases a willingness to check the other branches of government while simultaneously upholding the values of human rights and individual privacy.

item.title: Federal judge allows Muslim US citizen to sue over border detention---HOLD
item.dc:creator: cthompson
